iv
Functional-Linear Genetic Programming: Automatic Discovery
and Reuse of Functions Through Linear Genetic Programming
by
Abdolhamid Badiozamani
Master of Science in Computer Science
San Diego State University, 2011
This project combines list-based Genetic Programming (LGP) and a basic
programming language to study the effectiveness of automatic arithmetic and Boolean logic
discovery. The programming language is designed to be as simple as possible having no
more than nine total unary instructions, to reduce the inductive bias present in GA
experiments, and instead shift the burden of bias to the training data presented to the system.
The goal of the project was to allow for more complex operations to be derived from the nine
basic hard-coded instructions of the programming language.
The system was able to derive functions several layers removed from the basic
instructions. For example, the addition operator was derived based on the increment
instruction and the multiplication instruction was discovered based on the previously derived
addition operator.

xiii
I would like to thank my father who taught me sacrifice and my wife whose support
fuels me. I would also like to thank my thesis advisor, Dr. Joseph Lewis without whose
guidance and patient direction none of this work would be possible.
I wish also to thank
Montezuma Publishing whose formatting rules have so greatly enhanced the readability of
this document.
Throughout all natural systems, from ant colonies to our global economy to snow
flake formation, we have observed a recurring pattern: that a very large number of
independent agents interacting with each other at a local level cause a complex global
behavior to emerge. There are numerous studies and numerous names, to describe the various
aspects of this phenomenon: Chaos Theory, Complex Adaptive Systems, Non-linear
Dynamical Systems, Emergent Behavior, etc. Within the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI),
these natural systems have inspired a new approach which, with its many technical
variations, are collectively called “population-based” techniques or algorithms.
Population-based techniques stand in stark contrast to traditional methods of solving
AI problems. Whereas the traditional approach to AI focused on rigid structures applied to
strict and deterministic mathematical algorithms, population-based techniques rely on
starting out with a large number of candidate solutions and making small adjustments to
these solutions thus bringing them closer a particular goal. If we liken these two techniques
to creating a statue having a certain set of characteristics, then with traditional AI methods
the construction would take place by arranging various sized blocks of stone on top of each
other until the statue is completed. Whereas with population-based techniques, a large
number of stones are deemed candidates and are each analyzed and chiseled or molded
together repeatedly until one of them satisfies the characteristics of the statue we’re
attempting to make.
While both population-based techniques and traditional AI methods have
demonstrated their viability in a wide number of fields, they both suffer from weaknesses
that arise from their strengths. Traditional AI methods tend to operate very quickly and are
able to give exact answers. But they lack the ability to adapt to a changing environment and
due to their all-or-nothing design will yield total failure in unfamiliar situations. Population-
based techniques require intensive computation and are relatively slow and rarely give an
exact “best” answer. However, they can be very flexible and responsive to shifting
environmental conditions and are able to give “good enough” answers. The strengths and
weaknesses of these two systems can be described as the difference between a digital
calculator and a person performing calculations intuitively. One might be able to give a
rough answer to a complex problem without referencing any equations. For example, we
might ask “what is the farthest that anyone can throw a baseball”? Without referencing the
weight of the ball, the strength of the thrower, nor the wind resistance we’re able to make a
“good enough” guess that this answer is measured in yards and not miles. A calculator on the
other hand can give a highly precise answer to the same problem, but only if it is properly
loaded with the correct set of equations and figures. Otherwise, it will simply not be able to
even attempt the problem. Of course, the intuitive answer draws upon the knowledge and
experience of the person attempting to solve the problem. It is this set of assumptions that
eliminate all of the invalid possibilities from the whole set of answers. The assumptions
gleaned from past experiences form the bias of the intuitive problem solver.
The following study describes a project that attempts to minimize the inductive bias
of a population-based system by transferring the burden of learning to the set of experiences
that are exposed to the system. The system proposed is a simple list-based Genetic
Programming approach applied to a minimal instruction set. It uses A-Life inspired
techniques for determining fitness and for evaluation of individual programs within the
population. The problem domain to be explored using this technique is inspired by Lenat's
"Automated Mathematician" project [11] which used a very small set of mathematical
operations upon which new operations or theorems were discovered. Thus, the goal is to
initially expose the system to simple Boolean logic and mathematical problems and
subsequently, as the system gains experience from the initial exposure, to present it with
more complex problems.
The focus of the project is to study the reduction of inductive bias in evolutionary
algorithms. One of the ways in reducing this bias is to begin with the smallest possible scope
which in this case are the nine basic instructions. Metaphorically, the system attempts to
emulate a biological organism that emerges from a given natural environment. Within this
environment, the nine hard-coded instructions are representing the basic physical elements
that are present in all biological living systems such as Carbon, Hydrogen and Oxygen.
We are thus limited to these instructions and do not rely on a programming language
such as LISP, C or even machine code. Furthermore, the language does not provide any
constants and only through the initial zero values of memory buffers are constants derived.
As such, it cannot solve certain tasks that require counting the number of times a given
operation has been performed. This limits the type of tasks that can be solved. For example,
division or modulo could not be derived.
Finally, the I/O operations of the language are limited to the 16-bit positive integer
finite space. Any edge cases are simply treated as the maximum or minimum allowable
value, 255 and 0 respectively.
The general problem domain for the field of AI is to create software that acts
intelligently. The definition of what constitutes intelligent behavior varies, however a modern
and generally accepted position is that an intelligent system is one that has a set of goals, is
able to perceive its environment, and will take actions that are likely to lead it to reach its
goals without human intervention [19].
Early AI methods focused on creating a set of directions for a computer to follow in
order to solve a problem. This approach was more formally presented by Newell and Simon
[14] as the Physical Symbol System Hypothesis (PSSH). which proposes an AI system that is
composed of a number of symbols that correspond to outside concepts, and rules that govern
how those symbols can interact with each other. Together, the combination of a single rule
and the symbols it operates on form an "expression". The combination of all of the possible
expressions make up the "problem search space". From this finite, though usually very large
search space, the most favorable expression at a given moment in time must be sought by the
system as the "best" action to take. These systems have achieved great success in areas such
as game programming or logic problem solving. For example, a PSSH system is ideal for a
game of chess because the objects that the symbols in the system represent, the chess pieces
and board, never change since new kinds of pieces are never added or removed from the
game. Furthermore, the rules governing game play as well as the object of the game are also
always static. As such, a very clean and exact one-to-one mapping can be attained, yielding a
simple and highly effective PSSH AI system. PSSH systems have also been expanded and
enhanced to solve more complex problems in a variety of fields that require the vast and deep
knowledge of an expert in that field. These systems are known as "Expert Systems" [3] and
have been deployed successfully in numerous environments from vehicle diagnostics to
medical assessments. In these domains, the rules for determining an ideal solution do not
change very rapidly. In instances that a new discovery or method becomes available, the
existing rules are periodically updated and the system continues to function as normal.
But in situations where the rules and symbols change relatively rapidly over time,
PSSH systems do not perform well since the internal model of symbols quickly becomes out
of sync with the reality of their environment. This drawback is known as "brittleness" and is
a major criticism of PSSH systems as put forth by Rodney Brooks [2] who argues that
instead of using symbols to create an internal representational model of the world in the
system, the world itself should be used as the model and simply referenced by the system
through sensors as often as is necessary. This is known as the "embodiment" principle and is
presented in Brooks' "subsumption architecture" and has been very successful in the field of
robotics. The architecture is inspired by natural organisms and employs a set of layered rules,
with higher level rules in charge of directing the system towards an overall goal, and lower
level rules managing ever more local and basic functions. The architecture relies heavily on
its input sensors to perceive its environment.
While Brooks' subsumption architecture is a stark departure from PSSH systems,
neither system uses past experiences to improve its ability to solve future problems. PSSH
systems have unchanging symbols and static rules and the subsumption architecture is said to
be "reactive" and "lives in the moment" with no sense of a distant past that helps to plan for
the future [8]. Other systems that can achieve this are collectively grouped into the "Machine
Learning" branch of AI. One such system is the Learning Classifier Systems or (LCS)
developed by John Holland [6] which provided a unique approach for using a system's past
experiences to affect its future. The LCS uses a technique called "reinforcement learning"
that rewards or punishes a sequence of actions that the system has taken in the past based on
the desirability of the outcome of those actions. In addition to outputting a sequence of
actions, the LCS also includes a subsystem that is used to generate new types of actions. This
subsystem was described by Holland as a "Genetic Algorithm" which uses the evolutionary
strategy of chromosome crossover and mutation to create new types of action and simulate
novelty.
A Genetic Algorithm (GA) is a population-based supervised learning method by
which a large search space is scoured to find an ideal candidate [5]. GAs have many
parameters that are adjustable and many different variations in implementation. They have
been employed successfully in numerous applications from bioinformatics [16] to circuit
design [7]. GAs can be decomposed into three main subsystems: the fitness function,
genotype/phenotype encoding and the crossover/mutation strategy.
As with other population-based techniques, GAs operate by starting out with a large
pool of individual candidates that are usually generated with random initial values. Then,
through manipulating the individuals over successive iterations the population moves ever
closer toward an optimal solution until one of the candidate solutions in the population is
considered to be "good enough" at solving the problem at which point the operation
terminates. What differentiates one population-based technique from another is in the way
that the population is represented and manipulated which ultimately affects the emergence of
a solution.
GAs are inspired by the theory of natural selection and evolutionary change over
time. For GAs, the metaphor that is used for representation is that of a genetic sequence.
Each individual solution is "born" out of a specific genetic sequence, and thus identical
genetic sequences produce identical actual solutions. Natural selection and mating is used for
manipulation of individuals by selectively removing unfit individuals and replacing them
with the "children" of the survivors. These children form a new generation and are spawned
by combining the genetic sequence of two parents from the previous generation. As such,
subsequent generations carry over genes that have proven to be successful, and over time
yielding ever more effective individuals.
A fitness function is an heuristic algorithm used to score a candidate solution. As with
other supervised learning methods, GAs use fitness functions to determine the fitness of each
individual candidate in the population. It is this score that will determine whether an
individual will survive to the next generation or die and be replaced. The fitness function is a
source of "inductive bias" in that the knowledge used to score an individual candidate is
induced by the programmer. Since this knowledge needs to apply to any potential candidate
in general, it requires careful planning and deep knowledge of the problem domain.
The design of the fitness function is beset by the speed or quality trade-off. A high
quality and meaningful score may take a long time to compute but may yield a solution in
fewer generations. A less accurate score may take much less time to compute thus allowing
for more generations or a larger population set to be processed in the same amount of time.
For example, some popular fitness functions include the Minkowski distance (e.g. Euclidean
[9] or Manhattan [18]) or the Hamming distance [21] between the candidate solution and the
goal. These equations are very fast calculations which free up the system to produce more
generations. Conversely, a fitness function may involve invoking a large simulation to run
several trials of a candidate before returning a multi-part score. Of course, each individual
that has to be evaluated would take considerable system resources thus sacrificing the
number of generations that can be calculated in the same time period.
In keeping with the biological metaphor of genetics, a genotype is the genetic makeup
of an individual. Conversely, the phenotype of an individual are the traits that are actualized
based on the genes. For example, the "XX" or "XY" chromosome is said to be the gender
genotype of an individual mammal. A mammal with the "XY" chromosome will be born
male whereas one with the "XX" chromosome will be born female. The actual gender of the
live mammal is called the phenotype. In many situations, such as eye color or hair color or
skin pigmentation one gene is overridden by another and is not necessarily actualized. This is
an important phenomenon as it allows a particular gene to be carried recessively and
manifested in future generations where it may be useful.
Within GAs, the genotype is generally represented as a string of bits. The decoding
algorithm then analyzes this bit string and constructs, or "births" the individual for analysis
by the fitness function, or perhaps as the final result. The algorithm must be designed to be
able to handle all possible bit strings even though some strings may not manifest viable
individuals since the process of generating the genotype is not deliberate.
The genotype/phenotype encoding and decoding process greatly affects the
performance of a GA. The engineering trade-off is in the size of the genotype and the amount
of traits that it carries. A smaller size translates into faster computation of generations.
However, the smaller size also means there are fewer traits that are captured and can be
analyzed which affects the fitness function's ability to properly score an individual thus
yielding poor candidates. A larger genotype encoding takes more computation but allows the
fitness function to more accurately score each candidate. If the genotype is too detailed,
however, the computation required for each generation grows and the number of dimensions
that must be analyzed are also increased. It is the consideration of these trade-offs that are
also a source of inductive bias as the decisions have to be made by the system's author whose
knowledge of the problem domain needs to be applied.
The crossover and mutation strategy refers to the algorithm used to generate new
individuals for subsequent generations using the current population set. For each generation,
the individuals in the population are scored and a certain percentage are eliminated. Their
place is taken by new individuals that are generated using the survivors. Typically, two
parents are selected from the survivor pool and their genes are then combined through a
"crossover" algorithm. This algorithm alternates between each parent and copies segments of
varying lengths onto the new child individual. The simplest form of crossover first duplicates
one parent's genes onto a child, then selects a random section from the other parent's genes
and copies the values at the same location onto the child. There are numerous variations of
crossover, but the purpose of all of them is to generate new individuals from two or more
candidates selected from the previous generation's pool. Here, the selection process is also a
design decision with numerous variations that consider the fitness of individuals when
selecting them for crossover. It is through the selection and crossover process that over many
generations more and more healthy individuals emerge as their genes are passed on. This
phenomenon is formally presented by Holland as the "Schema Theorem" [6].
Once a new child candidate has been generated using cross-over, it may or may not
be selected for mutation. The purpose of mutation is to introduce novelty into the population
and is again inspired by natural observations of reproduction. Mutation is generally
performed by inverting one or more bits in the child 's genotype prior to releasing it back into
the general population pool. The frequency with which new offspring are mutated and the
magnitude of mutation are all trade-offs that must be considered by the author and are
generally tuned through trial and error for the specific application. One popular technique is
to vary the mutation rate depending on the state of the population as a whole. By increasing
the mutation rate as the population becomes more homogeneous we introduce more novelty
into a stagnated gene pool in the hopes of discovering a more healthy individual. By keeping
the mutation rate low in early generations we increase the efficiency of the algorithm in
selecting the healthiest candidates from an already heterogeneous supply.
Genetic Programming (GP) is a programming technique that employs GAs to search
for an optimal solution [9]. In essence, it attempts to answer the question "what sequence of
programming instructions solves the given problem?" Genetic Programming has had some
success in industrial applications such as circuit synthesis [10] and robotics [17] but is still an
area of continuing research. GPs mainly fall under two main categories: list-based and tree-
based.
Tree-based Genetic Programming (TGP) typically generates programs in a functional
language such as LISP being the phenotype of each individual within the underlying GA.
Conversely, the genotype of the individuals are expressions consisting of a set of operators
and terminals. The operators are functions that take a specific number of parameters as their
arguments and are evaluated down to a single value. The terminals are the values that are
known at the time of the program's evaluation (i.e. variables, constants and literals). Each
individual's genotype is represented as a tree with each branch consisting of an operator at its
root and either an expression or terminal as its leaves. For example, the expression "2 + X"
would be represented as a tree with the root node being the operator "+", the left leaf being
the terminal literal "2" and the right leaf being the terminal variable "X".
The tree representation is key in the crossover operations of the underlying GA.
When two parent candidates are to be crossed over, one parent's contents are first duplicated
onto the target child individual. Then, one or more branches from the other parent are copied
onto the child, overwriting the previous branches at that location, thus creating a new
individual with traits from both parents. For example, if parent A is the expression "(2 + X) +
Y" and parent B is "(2 * Y) – 3" one potential child candidate could be formed by first
copying parent A's structure onto the child and then swapping its left branch "(2 + X)" with
the left branch of parent B "(2 * Y)" yielding the result "(2 * Y) – Y" (Figure 2.1). Note that
the crossover method guarantees that there are no invalid programs generated since only the
branches, which themselves are valid sub-programs, are swapped with other branches. For
mutation, a candidate's terminal or operator is replaced using a set of previously defined
operators and terminals. Again the mutation operation guarantees that the candidates are all
valid subprograms since terminals are by definition interchangable and also by ensuring that
the arity of the operator being replaced matches the arity of the new operator. For example, a
binary operator will only be mutated by being swapped out with another binary operator.
Finally, once the pool has been repopulated with new candidates, each are scored
using the fitness function. This function scores the individuals by first converting the syntax
tree into an executable function. Then, the function is evaluated and the result is compared
with the overall goal and the difference, or some other variation of distance, is used as the
score value. The underlying GA algorithm continues purging the low-scoring individuals and
repopulating the pool until the termination criteria is reached. This criteria is generally a set
number of generations or a specific fitness score threshold.
List-based Genetic Programming, sometimes referred to as Linear Genetic
Programming (LGP), differs from TGP in several fundamental ways. First, LGPs generally
use imperative languages such as C or assembly language as the phenotype of the individuals
as they are faster to execute than functional programming languages. Additionally, the
genotypical representation of the individuals are a list of instructions in sequence instead of a
syntax tree [1,15]. This also affects crossover/mutation operations as they are no longer
swapping branches that represent internal functions but rather exchanging a section of each
individual that represents a set of individual instructions. For example, if parent A is the
program "INPUT, ADD, MULTIPLY" and parent B is "ADD, SUBTRACT, STORE" then
one potential child candidate could be formed by first copying parent A's sequence of
instructions onto the child and then replacing the second half with parent B's genes yielding
the result "INPUT, SUBTRACT, STORE" (Figure 2.2). For mutation, one or more of the
candidate's individual instructions are replaced by a random one from the set of all possible
instructions.
Note that unlike TGP, no consideration is given to the arity of the operator nor is
there any other form of error checking needed. This is due to the underlying language's
design. By removing the requirements for block creation and termination, the only
requirement for an imperative language program is that one instruction follows another.
When a child candidate is generated using crossover, there is a possibility that some
of the instructions in an individual are ineffective. For example, consider the program "a = b
+ c; d = b * 2; return d;". Note that the first instruction does not affect the return value of the
program. These ineffective instructions are known as "introns" [20]. Introns can hinder the
execution speed of programs and are one cause of bloat. They are sometimes removed during
conversion from genotype to phenotype prior to execution for fitness evaluation [1] but they
are usually not removed from the genes of the individual as they may become useful if they
are passed on to subsequent generations.
The main goal of the project is to yield a system that learns from its own experiences
instead of inferring knowledge from its author. One such source of knowledge is the
programming language implementation. A complex and feature-rich language carries with it
a great deal of the author's inductive bias since that knowledge is directly bestowed upon the
system in the form of hard-coded implementation. Conversely, a simple and basic
programming language minimizes this bias. Thus the language used in this study was devised
with the intent to keep its instructions limited to the most basic and universal truths. The
simplicity of the language design led naturally to the LGP approach being selected as the
search mechanism. This search mechanism is used to find the best expressions to satisfy a
given criteria from the set of all valid expressions. Elements of functional programming have
also been incorporated into the system in order to allow composition of higher level
operations using the more basic instructions.
Overall, the system discovers solutions to problems by using the given training data
to generate subprograms built from the original basic instructions. For each training data set
given, the system invokes the LGP engine and adds the resulting program with the highest
fitness to the set of discovered programs (Figure 3.1). This process is then repeated several
times or until an exact match is found or a predetermined threshold is reached.
This approach allows the system to build upon past successes and discoveries. The
project's implementation of the system also allows for a single run to use multiple training
memory buffer pairs each with its own input and target/goal buffer. The effect is that for each
iteration each candidate individual is tested against all training pair memory buffers and their
fitness results averaged. For example, if the system is given the task to discover the addition
function it will be necessary to give the system more than just one example of addition since
otherwise a very specific program will be discovered that solves that the particular example.
But by providing multiple training memory buffer pairs we limit the system to producing a
method that satisfies all of the mappings instead.
The programming language does not use any terminals or constants other than what is
supplied in the input buffer. Instructions take, as the situation warrants, input from the next
available memory position in input memory. There are also instructions that can advance or
regress the current position in both input memory as well as the instruction pointer. There is
also a temporary memory buffer that can be used to save and load values as needed for future
use.
The basic instructions can be classified according to function:
Arithmetic/Boolean: Unary operators on integer/Boolean data.
Instruction Pointer Control: Affects how the subsequent instruction is to be executed.
Temporary Storage: Saves/Loads values for use by other instructions.
Data Pointer Control: Affects which input value is to be used for the subsequent
instruction.
The following is a brief description of each type of basic instruction and the class to
which it belongs:
INC: Increment (Boolean/Arithmetic). Reads the next available value in the input
buffer, increments that value by 1 and returns the result. A value of 255 is not
incremented.
DEC: Decrement (Boolean/Arithmetic). Reads the next available value in the input
buffer, decrements that value by 1 and returns the result. A value of 0 is not
decremented.
IF: If condition (Instruction Pointer Control). Reads the next available value in the
input buffer and if the value is even (i.e. the first bit is 0) the next instruction is
skipped. Otherwise, the next instruction is executed as normal.
LOOP: Loop structure (Instruction Pointer Control). Reads the next available
value in the input buffer and executes the next instruction repeatedly for as many
times as the input value. If the input value is zero, the next instruction is not executed.
PUSH: Push/Save value (Temporary Storage). Reads the next available value in
the input buffer and saves it to temporary memory without advancing the input
buffer's pointer.
POP: Pop/Load value (Temporary Storage). Reads the next available value in
temporary memory. If there are no previous values saved, an error condition is set and
the program terminates early, causing all subsequent instructions to not be executed.
NEXT: Next value (Data Pointer Control). Reads the next available value in the
input buffer and returns it, effectively incrementing the input buffer's pointer by one.
PREV: Previous value (Data Pointer Control). Decrement's the input buffer
pointer's position by one and returns the value at that position.
NOP: No Operation. Performs no operation. Included for GA performance checks.
Programs are defined using the Composite pattern [4] with a base unit consisting of a
single instruction. The notation for describing a program starts with an open curly brace
character"{" followed by a comma-separated list of instruction codes or other programs and
terminated with a close curly brace character "}". For example,
{ INC, DEC }
is a program that
contains the two basic instructions to first increment the next value and then decrement the
value after that.
Programs can also contain other programs (i.e. "subprograms"). For example
{ INC {
INC, DEC } }
is a program that contains the basic instruction to increment the next value
followed by the previous example's program. Any combination of instructions and
subprograms are considered valid programs. For example, one possible instruction sequence
for summing an array of integers whose first parameter defines the length of the array would
be
{ { INC } { LOOP { LOOP { INC } { INC } DEC } PREV } }
. The term "operation" is used to
mean either a single instruction or a subprogram.
Multiple operations that are part of the same program are said to be in the same
"context". Whereas operations that are part of a subprogram are said to be either at a higher
level context or lower level context. The previous example of the series sum program has
multiple subprograms and is three levels deep.
Each program can be measured using three metrics: size, cost and energy. The "size"
metric (
) refers to the number of instructions or subprograms that are in the root context of
the program. The "cost" of a program (
) is a recursive definition calculated by taking the
sum of the size of the program and the cost all of its subprograms. A program's "energy" (
is calculated only by running the program using a given input set. Each instruction within
each subprogram that is executed increments the root program's energy value. This value is
also incremented every time a subprogram is invoked thus accounting for the overhead
involved in creating a new context. For example, the program
{ { INC } DEC }
is said to have
an energy value of three. The energy value is important as it allows a maximum threshold to
be set in order to limit the amount of time and resources a program takes to execute.
The combination of these metrics also gives insight into a program's complexity. Note
that for all cases
. Furthermore, note that
is always dependent on the input data
and can only be calculated by executing the program. The following is a sample compilation
of information that can be gleaned from a program's metrics:
The program is simple and does not contain any subprograms.
: The program contains one or more subprograms.
: The ratio of subprograms to individual instructions. Smaller values represent a
larger number of subprograms. A value smaller than 50% indicates more subprograms
than instructions and is a sign of inefficiency as the program is taking more time in
unnecessary context switches.
Programs are executed by individually performing each instruction within its
subprograms in order from left to right and are terminated when one of three conditions are
satisfied:
There are no further operations to execute within the root context.
Input has been requested but there are no further input values available.
The program reaches its maximum allowable energy threshold
I/O operation rules play an important role in the semantics of the language and are at
the core of simulating value passing from one operation to the next. Instructions generally
take a single integer value, operate on that value and output a result. The algorithm for
determining where the next input value comes from and where the output value is stored
allows the instructions to work on arrays of integers as well as the results of chained
functions.
In the simplest case, a single instruction takes the first value from input memory and
its output is stored in the first position in output memory (Figure 3.2).
If there are multiple instructions within the same program, each instruction takes the
next value from input memory and its output is stored in the next position in the output
memory (Figure 3.3). This one-to-one mapping allows programs to be written such that they
operate on arbitrary sized arrays of input. For example, the program
{ INC, DEC }
takes two
integers as its input, and outputs two integers with the first being one greater and the second
being one less than the respective input values.
In cases where an instruction is followed by a subprogram, the behavior is the same
as above (Figure 3.4). That is, the first instruction takes the first value from input memory
and stores its result in the first position of output memory, and the subprogram's first
instruction takes the subsequent value(s) from input memory and stores its value in the first
position of output memory.
For example, the program
{ INC { INC } }
first increments the first input value and
stores it as the first output value. Then, the inner subprogram
{ INC }
is called which takes the
next input value, then increments and stores the result in the subsequent output location.
Essentially, this program is equivalent to
{ INC, INC }
For programs that are nested within each other, the result of one subprogram is
injected into the input buffer for use in the subsequent context. This is achieved through an
internal memory buffer that is responsible for holding the resulting values of a subprogram
for use by the next instruction or subprogram. In cases where there is no subsequent
instruction or subprogram its contents are simply copied onto the output memory buffer
(Figure 3.5).
For example, the program
{ { INC } INC }
increments the first value from input
memory, then injects the results in the internal memory buffer. Then, the subsequent
instruction is given the input from this internal memory buffer and its results are stored in
output memory. If the internal memory buffer is exhausted, the input memory buffer is used
to draw input.
The final component to I/O operations is the use of a temporary stack buffer that is
available to programs for use within their own context through the PUSH and POP
instructions. Each subprogram creates its own temporary stack buffer which is discarded
when the subprogram terminates.
The Instruction Pool is a singleton object that manages all known programs in the
system at any given point in time. It is effectively the long-term memory of the system as
new programs are discovered by the LGP engine. Each instruction and program is assigned a
unique integer identifier by the Instruction Pool and is guaranteed not to be an exact
duplicate of another program (Figure 3.6). Finally, the Instruction Pool is used as a resource
for selecting a random instruction. This will become important in the mutation phase of the
LGP's generational process.

text.b: Figure 3.6. Instruction pool internal representation structure.

page.text: Several sample program traces are provided to illustrate the execution method and I/O
operations of the programming language.
Program 1: This program takes one argument, increments its value and outputs the
result:
{ INC }
The program simply executes the INC instruction which takes one argument, and
outputs its value.
Program 2a: This program takes one argument and outputs the same argument:
{{ INC } DEC }
The program starts out by creating a new context, then executing Program 1 above.
The result of Program 1 is then decremented by one and the result is output.
Program 2b: This program is an alternate implementation of Program 2a:
{ PUSH, POP }
The program starts out by storing the first input value onto the temporary stack, then
removing the value from the temporary stack and outputting the result. Note that the input
memory buffer's pointer is not incremented in this case, which will have a different effect on
a parent program's execution than Program 2a.
Program 3a: This program takes two arguments and outputs the second:
{ NEXT { { INC } DEC } }
The program starts by skipping the first input value, then invoking Program 2a above.
Program 3b: This program is an alternate implementation of Program 3a:
{ NEXT { INC } DEC }
The program starts by skipping the first input value, then incrementing the subsequent
input value and finally decrementing the result and outputting the original value of the
second argument. Note that the cost value of this program is smaller than Program 3a.
Program 4: This program adds two integers together and outputs the result:
{ LOOP { INC } }
The program starts out by reading the first argument's value and executing Program 1
that many times. For example, if the input arguments were "4 3" then the program would
execute Program 1 four times effectively yielding the following unrolled version:
INC } INC } INC }
. Note that the input value read for each subsequent INC instruction is
actually the result of the previous operation that has been injected into the queue.
Program 5: This program increments the members of a given arbitrary sized integer
array:
{ LOOP, INC }
The program starts by taking as its first input the size of the array. Then incrementing
each value of the array and outputting the result. For example, if the input arguments were "3
1 2 3" the program would execute the INC operation three times effectively yielding the
following unrolled version:
{ INC, INC, INC }
resulting in the output array "2 3 4".
The LGP is the system's search engine that looks for programs that satisfy various
input-goal memory buffer training pairs. It may be invoked numerous times within a single
attempt at solving a given problem. At the end of each iteration, the best resultant program is
stored in the Instruction Pool thus allowing it to become usable as a subprogram in future
iterations.
As with all GAs, the LGP engine has various tunable parameters. The following is a
description of the tunable parameters and their effects on the performance of the overall
engine:
Maximum Number of Invocations: The LGP engine may be invoked several times
and with each successive iteration the best result is stored in the Instruction Pool for
use as a potential part of another program in future invocations. This process
terminates immediately if a perfect solution is found. However, in many cases it is
necessary to invoke the LGP search multiple times in order to build several
subprograms over time that can be used to further the goal. The Maximum Number of
Invocations is the maximum number of times the LGP engine is invoked before
giving up on the search. Smaller values may not yield enough opportunity for the
LGP engine to work towards building subprograms for use in an ultimate solution.
Increasing this number gives the LGP engine more opportunities to build
subprograms, at the expense of processing time. Furthermore, if the LGP engine is
unable to solve the problem, it begins emitting the same solutions repeatedly with no
progress.
For the scope of the given experiments and through numerous trials a value of
seven (7) was seen as optimal since overall if a solution did exist, it could be found on
average within seven invocations. Trials were conducted with maximum invocations
ranging from two (2) to one hundred (100).
Population Size: The population size refers to the number of individuals that
comprise the population pool upon which the engine operates on. A population size
that is too small decreases performance by squeezing out diversity too rapidly as each
individual is a larger portion of the whole population. A small population size also
limits novelty and discovery through mutations as there are less actual mutations
being performed with each mutation having a much larger impact on the population
as a whole.
A population size that is too large pays a very heavy penalty in performance
since a larger population also affects the number of pruning, crossover, and fitness
evaluation operations.
For the purpose of this project, a population size of one-hundred (100)
individuals was deemed optimal. Trials were conducted with population sizes ranging
from twenty (20) to two-hundred (200) with all other factors remaining the same.
Maximum Number of Generations: The number of generations is the maximum
number of times the population pool is pruned and repopulated before terminating the
process. As with the Maximum Number of Invocations above, the LGP engine
terminates the search as soon as a perfect solution is found. However, in cases where
a perfect solution is not found, the engine terminates upon reaching the Maximum
Number of Generations. Increasing this value gives more opportunity for the
population to find on an optimal solution at the expense of processing time. However,
beyond a certain threshold the population will converge and successive generations
will not yield significant advances. If the number of generations is too small, the
engine will not have a chance to prune and modify the population enough to yield an
optimal solution.
For the purpose of this project, a Maximum Number of Generations value of
seventy-five (75) was selected. Trials were conducted with values ranging from
twenty (20) to two-hundred (200).
Crossover Rate: With each new generation, the population is pruned and replaced
with a new set of individuals. Each individual from the previous generation may be
mated with a different individual to generate a new offspring. This process is known
as crossover and the rate at which this process occurs is a tunable parameter known as
the Crossover Rate. If this value is too low, it takes a large number of generations to
advance the individuals in fitness as most individuals simply get carried over from the
previous generation. Conversely, if this value is too high, the small incremental gains
made by an individual may not have a chance to be passed on to subsequent
generations.
For the purpose of this project, a crossover rate of seventy percent (70%) was
deemed optimal.
Mutation Rate: As part of the crossover process, the child individual may or may not
be mutated. The mutation process introduces novelty by randomly changing a portion
of the individual's genotype. The Mutation Rate refers to the likelihood that mutation
will be triggered after crossover has taken place. If this rate is too high, it is likely to
disrupt the progress of the GA by erasing the incremental gains of fit individuals. If
the rate is too low, the system will have no way of overcoming local optima by trying
something new.
For the purpose of this study, the mutation rate was set to ten percent (10%) of
the crossover rate for an effective rate of seven percent (7%) of the overall population
for each generation.
The crossover/mutation method for the LGP drives the generation of new individuals
and solutions. This method is at the core of finding solutions in the search space and is highly
dependent on the genotype encoding of individuals.
The genotype of individuals in the population is represented by an array of integers.
These integers are simply nominal and carry no intrinsic numerical meaning. Rather, they are
the identifiers, or operation codes, of each operation as assigned by the Instruction Pool.
The genotypes are interpreted into complete programs by deciphering each operation
code using the Instruction Pool. The program and all of its operations are executed according
to their order in the genotype array. Note that subprograms are defined in the Instruction Pool
and not in the genotype of the individual. This implies that the genotype only carries the
instructions and subprograms for its own context. As such, there is no need for the individual
to maintain a tree-like structure for its subprograms, since each subprogram is responsible
solely for its own context.
For example, consider the program
{ { LOOP { INC } } DEC }
. This program can be
encoded as the following array [ 11, 2 ] where 11 refers to the subprogram
{ LOOP { INC } }
and 2 refers to the instruction DEC. The subprogram {
LOOP { INC } }
itself would be defined
by the instruction pool as the array [ 4, 10 ] where 4 refers to the instruction LOOP and 10
refers to the subprogram { INC }. Finally, the subprogram
{ INC }
is simply defined as [ 1 ]
referring to the instruction code for INC.
As the algorithm is repopulating a new generation, a crossover event is triggered
based on the Crossover Rate. When this event is triggered, two individuals must be selected
from the current generation to be mated together. This selection can be performed through
different algorithms. These include the Roulette Wheel Selector, Tournament Selector,
Uniform Selector, among others. For the purpose of this study the Uniform Selector was
chosen as it provided the simplest and most efficient algorithm. Both Roulette Wheel and
Tournament were used in different trials with similar performance results. The Uniform
selector works by giving equal selection probability to all individuals in the previous
population.
The crossover algorithm is responsible for generating a single individual, the "child",
from two other individuals, the "parents". The algorithm selected was a simple but slightly
modified variation of the standard two-point crossover method found in many GA systems:
a.
For the input parents A and B, let s be the lesser of
A
and
B
b.
Copy the contents of parent A onto the target child individual
c.
Select a random number x such that x < s/2
d.
Select a random number y such that s/2 < y < s
e.
Copy the contents of parent B from position x to position y onto the target child
individual
The mutation process is responsible for altering a given individual in order to
introduce novelty to the solution. In the case of programs, this alteration can take one of three
forms: switching one instruction for another, removing an operation from the program, or
adding an operation to the program.
The algorithm iterates through all operations of a program's root context and makes a
decision as to whether to mutate a given operation through a biased coin toss. This coin toss
uses the mutation rate as set in (3.3.1). Once it is determined that the given operation is to be
mutated, the Instruction Pool is referenced to select its replacement from the available set of
all operations. After all operations have been considered for mutation, the system performs
another biased coin toss using the same mutation rate to determine whether to add or remove
any operations from the new individual. If the coin toss succeeds then a second fair coin toss
is used to determine whether to remove or add an operation. If the system is to add an
operation, the Instruction Pool is again referenced in the same manner as the replacement
phase above to select an operation from the available set.
Note that a powerful aspect of this method is that it can replace an entire subprogram
in an individual with a single instruction and vice-versa, or add and remove large
subprograms through a single mutation.
The fitness function is described in general form and by its bounds and ranges.
From a philosophical stand point, the overall fitness of an individual is defined as
being "how well did the individual perform with regard to the amount of resources it
consumed". This valuation is inspired by natural selection in which the trade-off between
achievement and efficiency is rewarded through proliferation. In the case of programs, the
fitness function can be broken down to three major aspects that can be described by
answering the following questions:
Exertion "
": How well does the program's output count match the expected output
count?
Accuracy "
": How close does the program's output values come to the expected
output values?
Efficiency "
": How efficiently does the program achieve its result?
The first question aims to minimize overexertion or under-exertion of a program in
regard to its output. This is critical for generating building blocks that are able to become
subprograms of other larger programs. Conversely, if a program does not generate enough
output it is penalized for not finishing the job. Again if a program does not entirely output the
correct number of values, then in situations where the program's output is used as input for a
subsequent operation the integrity of the data is compromised. The value is calculated simply
as the difference between the number of values output by the program and the target number
of values that the ideal program should output. For example, if the output of a given program
is [ 3 1 1] but the goal is [ 5 ], then the exertion value (
) is 2 since the program's output
overexerts itself by outputting two values more than it needs.
The accuracy of a program is determined by the output's proximity to the goal and
aims to pressure the program to give correct values as its output. This is measured using the
average of two of the distance formulas discussed in (2.2.2): Euclidean difference (
using
simple integer subtraction and Hamming distance (
using unsigned bitwise operations. The
reason for using both instead of one exclusively is that through trials Hamming distance
yielded better results than Euclidean distance in certain cases and vice-versa. Whereas the
average yielded equal or better results in all cases. The difference formulas for both
Euclidean and Hamming distance only consider the available target values. For example, if
the output of a program is [ 3 1 1 ] and the goal is just [ 3 ], then the accuracy is said to be
zero, or exact, even though there are undesirable values at the end of the program's output.
The third factor is aimed at controlling code growth by applying parsimony pressure.
A program that can achieve its task with less instructions is considered to be more fit than
one that performs the same task using more resources. Factoring in this value causes the
trade-off between exploration and exploitation becomes a factor. If a program is given
survival priority because of its parsimony, it may not have a chance to combine with another
group of instructions to produce a correct solution. Conversely, eliminating this variable
results in a very large set of instructions that have no effect on the output of the program and
are wasteful both in terms of exploration as well as consuming resources. For the purposes of
the experiments, the efficiency value was simply set equal to the cost (
) of a program.
The fitness function is computed using these three components in the formula shown
in Figure 3.7.
The formula gives equal importance to accuracy (
) and exertion (
) by averaging the
two values together. If, using the original metaphor of fitness above, we consider this
averaged value to be the "achievement" of the program, then multiplying it by the amount of
resources the program consumed will embody our philosophy of "how well did the individual
perform with regard to the amount of resources it consumed."
For practical operation, this general formula was bounded by the following hard
limits:
A maximum cost threshold "K" is established that limits the cost value of a program
not to exceed this amount. For the experiments in this project, a value of one hundred
(100) was used.
A maximum I/O buffer size "S" is established that limits the total size of an input or
output buffer to not exceed this amount. For the experiments in this project, a value of
256 was used.
Given these hard limits, the range of the fitness formula can be calculated by using
the ranges of each component with the smallest value indicating the best possible fitness and
the maximum value indicating the worst possible fitness.
The Euclidean distance between two memory buffers A and B is denoted as
and
is calculated by taking the sum of the Euclidean distance
between each 16-bit
integer of each of the two buffers. The maximum Euclidean distance between two 16-
bit integers is 256, and the minimum difference is zero yielding a range of 0 ≤
256. In cases where the memory buffers are of different sizes, then the smaller size of
the two buffers is used and the values that have no corresponding counterpart from
one buffer to the other are not considered in the difference. As such, the maximum
possible difference is (256 * S) yielding a range of 0 ≤
AB
The Hamming distance between two memory buffers A and B is denoted as
AB
and
is calculated by taking the sum of the Hamming distance h between each 16-bit
integer of each of the two buffers. The maximum Hamming distance between two 16-
bit integers is 16, and the minimum difference is zero yielding a range of 0 ≤ h ≤ 16.
In cases where the memory buffers are of different sizes, then the smaller size of the
two buffers is used and the values that have no corresponding counterpart from one
buffer to the other are not considered in the distance. As such, the maximum possible
difference is (16 * S) yielding a range of 0 ≤
AB
Using the above ranges, we can calculate the range for accuracy
by simply using
the maximum and minimum values for each component yielding 0 ≤
The exertion value
between two buffers A and B is simply the difference in the size
of the buffers. Since a buffer can be completely empty, the minimum size for a buffer
is zero yielding a range of 0 ≤
Using the above ranges, we can calculate the final fitness value F for a given program
by using the maximum and minimum values for each component: 0 ≤ F ≤ 137 * (S/2)
*K. (See Figure 3.8 for the fitness function range.)
As with any system, there are numerous biases that are vital. Indeed, each of the
components of the system, by providing structure to govern the flow of execution, are by
themselves a source of inductive bias. We can compare these components to the laws of
physics in the natural world which direct all other systems in the universe. For example, if
instead of attracting two bodies gravity's effect was to repel, the world as we know it would
not exist. We are, in essence, attempting to provide a small universe in which the best
solutions can grow and flourish. A brief summary of the inductive bias of each component is
presented here:
1. Fitness Function: The fitness function is generally the primary source of inductive
bias in any metaheuristic learning method. After all, the judgement of whether one
individual is "better" than another is the very definition of bias. This function focuses
on emulating natural systems by binding the fitness to the amount of resources
consumed and then shifts the remaining burden of fitness to the training data.
Nevertheless, the decision to use one distance formula over another is clearly a large
source of inductive bias as even very small changes to this formula greatly affect the
outcome of the solutions produced.
2. Programming Language: The language with which to express a solution is also a
source of inductive bias since the language itself is unchangeable. Furthermore, as
evident in spoken languages, there are often concepts that cannot be translated from
one language to another without losing a significant amount of meaning. This reflects
the experiences of a culture that created words by necessity to express concepts that
another culture may not necessarily have been exposed to. By allowing the language
to create subprograms composed of the underlying basic instructions, we attempt to
minimize the impact of the language by essentially endowing the system with the
ability to form new "words" to the vocabulary in the form of subprograms.
3. Instruction Pool: The Instruction Pool's selection algorithm is a source of bias by
attempting to give equal selection probability to all operations that it stores when a
random operation is requested at mutation time. This algorithm is, of course, static
and unchangeable regardless of the types of problems to which the system is exposed.
Numerous trials were conducted with the aim of having the system discover the
instruction sequence for increasingly complex tasks. For each task, thirty (30) trials were
conducted with the same input-goal memory buffer pairs in order to explore the various
possible solutions that the system could discover. For many of the more complex
experiments we added "junk" values at the end of the input array as we wanted to ensure that
the solutions did not consider more input than necessary. In each section, the results of the
trials are presented in the following format:
a.
Description: A brief description of the task and what its aims are. All of the devised
tasks are familiar mathematical functions.
b.
Prerequisites: A set of one or more prior tasks that the system needs to have
discovered first before being able to find the solution to the given task. Often times,
solutions can be found without the strict need of the prerequisites but may make use
of them. In these cases, the prerequisite is marked as "Optional."
c.
Training Data Set: This is a mapping of input to goal target values. The system
considers the Training Data Set at once such that the solutions emitted have to match
all of the mappings and not just one or some in order to be considered correct.
d.
Solutions: Each task is presented to the system for a total of thirty (30) trials. The
total number of correct solutions that were found at the end of each trial are tallied
and the success rate calculated and posted here. Each unique solution is also posted
with the frequency and associated cost value associated.
The experiments that follow are divided into five categories of problems with each
subsequent category having problems that are more complex than the previous. Each
experiment in a given section was conducted after the system had solved all other problems
in previous sections. For example, any given problem in the third category was conducted
with a system that had experienced all problems in the first two categories. The system is
thus able to draw on its past experiences to solve newer more complicated problems much
akin to how a child is first taught how to stand, then walk, and then run. Of course, had the
system not been deliberately exposed to problems that form the building blocks of a more
complex problem it would simply not be able to produce any meaningful solutions. This is a
common problem for GAs that work on complex agents, in contrast with GAs that work on
optimizing a function [12,13].
The first set of tasks are so simple that a linear search mechanism would be sufficient
to find the correct solution. However, their discovery by the system is essential to being able
to solve more complex problems in the future. These trivial tasks are formally defined as any
task whose solutions are always Simple Programs (i.e.
Since the system is built using the nine basic instructions, the increment/decrement
operations are considered trivial. All the system has to do is find the solution by testing from
one of nine operations and indeed it is able to find this solution with a success rate of 100%.
The subprogram is always
{ INC }
for increment and
{ DEC }
for decrement. The task is
worthy of mention since once the solution is discovered it can be used as a subprogram for
other higher-level tasks, and has different semantics than just the instruction by itself due to
the value passing property of subprograms as outlined in (3.2.3).
Similar to the Increment/Decrement Single Value, this task is considered trivial since
the solution is extremely simple. The input is an array of integers with the size of the array
preceding the values. The system was able to find this solution with a success rate of 100%.
The subprogram is always
{ LOOP INC }
for increment and
{ LOOP DEC }
for decrement.
First Order tasks are those that may need to rely a Trivial Task to find the correct
solution. More formally, any task whose complete set of possible solutions contain at least
one Simple Program (i.e.
) is considered a First Order Task.
The Copy task simply takes an input value and returns that value as its output. This
may seem like a trivial task but in some cases, it cannot be accomplished unless the
Increment/Decrement Single Value subprogram is first discovered.
Prerequisites: Increment/Decrement Single Value (4.2.1) Optional.
