One question that arises is "how many variations of a particular problem's solution
occur"? For example, in Table 4.30 above there exists one solution that occurs far more
frequently than others. The issue is further influenced by the fitness function's parsimony
pressure that favors smaller solutions over larger ones in order to prevent code bloat. Thus,
the only way to get a high-fidelity measure of statistical variance on the solutions produced
would be to run experiments that are prohibitively costly and time-consuming with our
current computational capabilities and resources.
There were numerous unknowns when this project was first conceived, chief among
them was whether the system would be able to produce any meaningful solutions at all. The
idea of using a GA to search for solutions coupled with a long-term memory of previous
solutions was originally inspired by a desire to reverse-engineer the sequence of events in a
Complex Adaptive System (CAS) merely from a before and after picture. Clearly, this is an
ambitious achievement and is highly dependent on the "scope" of the problem. After all,
given a big enough scope even the human brain has trouble understanding how one set of
circumstances leads to the present observable results.
To better define the scope above, we can refer to the before and after picture as being
two snapshots of a CAS taken at different times. The shorter the time slice, the easier it is to
solve the problem. For example, if we take two pictures of a partly cloudy sky within two
minutes of each other, we can, with very good accuracy, be able to determine the wind speed
and wind direction that morphed the cloud into their present state. In fact, we're able to fairly
accurately predict the shape of a cloud from one second to the next, but it's rather difficult to
do the same after an hour.
In order to preserve generality, for the purposes of this discussion "time" is not
measured in seconds but rather in terms of the number of events that have occurred in the
system. If we consider that a weather system may take days to develop, whereas a chemical
reaction between cesium and water can be measured in microseconds, then the idea of using
"event count" as the measure of time becomes more appropriate.
In addition to the length of time, we must also include "granularity" as part of the
scope. Since most Complex Adaptive Systems are themselves composed of numerous
autonomous agents that themselves are Complex Adaptive Systems, drilling down to every
level to determine the exact behavior of each agent is impractical due to the sheer
computational costs involved. As such, at a certain point we simply assign a simple and
predictable algorithm that best fits a single agent's behavior in order to shortcut the large
computational cost. For example, meteorologists are able to make predictions about the
weather without having to predict the pattern of air molecules cooling each individual water
molecule for every cloud.
As it relates to this project, we use as our smallest granule the 16-bit positive integer
finite space and the nine basic instructions. The before and after pictures are represented by
the training data, and the time slice is determined by a valid solution's cost value. Although
the scope of the project is limited as such to match today's computational capabilities, the
results of the experiment nevertheless yielded some valuable insights that can perhaps be
applied to larger-scoped problems of a similar nature.
The exploration versus exploitation trade-off was very prominent as the problems that
the system was given became more and more complex. Since solutions for more complicated
problems were built using more simple ones, the number of possible operations to choose
from in the search process became increasingly large. Adding a single operation would
increase the possible search by a polynomial order.
For example, let's assume that a given solution that we are searching for is composed
of five total operations. If we limit the GA search engine to only look for solutions that are
exactly five operations long, then the search space is n
possible solutions, where n is the
total number of possible operations in the Instruction Pool to choose from. We arrive at this
solution by noting that there is an equal probability (1 / n) that a given operation will be
selected from the Instruction Pool for each of the five spots and that each operation may be
used multiple times. Since each spot is dependent on the previous operation having been
selected properly, the probability of selecting the correct five-operation sequence is (1 / n )
or one out of n
possibilities thus yielding a search space of n
Of course, the caveat in our simple calculation above is that the GA search is limited
to solutions that are exactly five operations long and for the experiments, no such limitation
was imposed. The GA search engine, therefore, needed to find a solution from within a
variable number of operations. However, due to the parsimony pressure applied in the fitness
function, programs tended to grow from smaller to larger sizes as the search progressed.
This, in essence, yielded a total search space of n + n
+ n
+ n
+ n
or O(n
). More generally
then, the search space can be expressed as being O(n
) where
is the size of the program as
defined in (3.2.2).
Clearly, as more and more operations are discovered and added to the Instruction
Pool the search space increases polynomially and puts more pressure on the GA search
mechanism. Nevertheless, it is more favorable to increase the total number of operations
available in the Instruction Pool, thus increasing the search space from n
to (n+1)
, than it is
to add more operations to a given solution which increases the search space from n
to n
For example, one solution for the NOT task (4.3.4) is
{ { DEC } PREV, IF, INC }
having a cost
value
of 6 and a size
of 4. If we consider that this solution was discovered using ten
possible operations (nine basic instructions and the { DEC } subprogram) then the minimum
size of the search space that the GA had to scour is 10 + 10
= 11,110. Another
possible solution for the same task is
{ PUSH, POP, IF, INC, DEC }
having the same cost value
of 6 and a size
of 5. But the size of the search space from which we can find this solution is
= 66,429 or 5.98 times larger. The results as presented in section (4.3.4) also
reflect this likelihood, as the latter solution was discovered less than half as many times as
the former.
This observation means that we may be able to gain polynomial performance
increases by putting pressure on the system to ensure that only operations that are useful are
kept in the Instruction Pool, or at the very least, are selected more frequently.
A major focus of this research has been to minimize the inductive bias present in
supervised learning methods which is generally manifested in the form of engineering
decisions that specialize the AI system. Throughout the project, it became apparent that some
sort of bias is, in fact, critical to finding solutions expediently. Without a favored general
direction in which to progress, the system ends up giving equal probability to selecting one
solution over the next from the given search space and is therefore performing a purely
arbitrary search.
However, inductive bias limits the system by cementing its decision paths to those
determined by the author of the system at inception. As such, the system is unable to evolve
to changing circumstances that the author may have not foreseen or taken into account in the
initial design. By minimizing the inductive bias of a system we minimize the need to have to
modify its internals to suit changing conditions. With this in mind, the system was designed
to make the least amount of assumptions possible about the types of problems it would be
solving. A key part of this approach was to make the system's interface to the outside world
highly generic. The memory buffers could be populated with input from a sensor and send
output to a robot or, as was the focus of this project, attempt to discover arithmetic and
Boolean logic operations.
Of course, there was no guarantee that the system would be able to produce any
useful solutions for any of the problems that it encountered. As expected, for complex
solutions, the "raw" system (i.e. a system that had not been exposed to any previous
problems) was not be able to produce any solutions that solved the task. However, if the
system was exposed to simpler problems upon which the more complex task was predicated
upon, it was able to generate the more complicated solutions easily. For example, the
Multiplication task (4.6.1) could not be solved without the Summation task (4.5.3) which
itself could not be solved without the system having previously solved the Addition task
(4.4.3). But once exposed to Addition and then Summation it was able to solve the
Multiplication task routinely. Here, our bias is apparent in the decision to train the system to
learn how to add first before exposing it to the sum training data and finally the
multiplication data. But this bias can be termed the "trainer's bias" since the trainer can be
anyone, or anything. This shifting of bias from the author of the system to a trainer is
significant because it demonstrates a system that, in theory, is trainable in a wide range of
problems without internal modifications.
Since the system derives its programs by testing different combinations of
instructions and subprograms, it is not bound by the same set of rules as a human
programmer might be when it comes to writing new programs. As such, the diversity of the
programs that were generated for solving the same task was surprising given that the rule-
based thought process for a human generated program would not necessarily yield so many
different variations. This phenomenon was particularly apparent in lower order tasks. For
example, the Boolean AND task (4.3.5) was expected to return the result
{ IF, PREV { { INC }
DEC } }
or some minor variation thereof as its only solution. And yet, the far more popular
and simpler version of the task was much different:
{ LOOP { INC } DEC }
. This latter program
exploits the edge case of the DEC instruction that does not decrement input values below
zero, demonstrating that the system is agnostic in trying different combinations of
instructions.
Perhaps due to the same reasons as above, many of the tasks needed to have their
input training data padded with spurious numbers to prevent the system from exploiting the
termination of input in solving their problems. For example, the Copy task (4.3.1) would
sometimes return solutions such as { PUSH, POP, INC } or { { INC } DEC, DEC } which
would satisfy an input buffer consisting of a single input value since by the time the third
instruction would be executed the program would automatically terminate due to lack of
input data. This would then cause problems with operations that depended on the Copy task
but which happened to have more input data available than the solution was expecting. We
considered this not as a bug in the system but a bug in the training data which was corrected
by appending arbitrary values to the end of the input buffer that was intended to be ignored
by correct solutions.
A major improvement to the system would be to increase the performance of the GA
search engine. As discussed in (5.1), by eliminating unnecessary operations from the
Instruction Pool, we're able to reduce the search space of the GA thus increasing its
performance polynomially. Since the Instruction Pool is responsible for selecting a random
operation during the mutation phase of the GA, if it is biased towards selecting a more
"useful" operation rather than giving all operations equal probability, the solutions that are
produced by the GA may be more fit thus saving numerous generations of search in the GA
that would otherwise have to be executed in search of the best random mutation.
We can measure how "useful" an operation is through different mechanisms, but a
good metric of usefulness may be usage count. This can be measured by incrementing a
counter for each operation every time that operation is invoked or at least employed in a
successful solution. Then, instead of using an equal probability random selection routine, we
can employ a simple Least-Recently-Used (LRU) algorithm to rank the operations by their
usage count. Once the operations are ranked, we would use a biased coin toss selection
algorithm to more frequently return the more "useful" operations whenever the Instruction
Pool is asked to supply an operation for use in mutations in the GA. In essence, we can view
the individual operations as having individual fitnesses depending on the amount of times
they are used or invoked.
This mechanism is intended to simulate cellular atrophy present in biological systems.
The expected result is that it will be an efficient means to leverage exploitation at a relatively
small expense of exploration. We should anticipate a feedback loop as well since an
operation that is likely to be selected for mutation due to a biased coin toss has more of a
chance to be executed which further increases its chances to be selected again.
One way to address the issue of feedback may be to use a rank-based selection
algorithm similar to that used in [12]. That is, once the usage counts have been determined,
sort each operation by its usage count, then use a biased coin toss that favors a given solution
based on its ranking relative to all others. By using this method, we are able to reduce the
likelihood that an instruction that gets heavy usage will completely dominate.
One of the observations throughout the experiments was that there were numerous
cases where the solutions had unnecessary operations that did not affect the overall result and
could therefore be eliminated to improve the performance of the individual program. While
the fitness function applies pressure through the use of the cost value
, it does not entirely
eliminate the problem. For example, the NOP instruction appears in solutions for four of the
tasks upon which the experiments were performed: Duplicate (4.3.3), Or (4.3.6), Addition
(4.4.3), and Nor (4.4.5). The reason for this is that the GA and fitness function are designed
to return a solution as soon as a perfect match is found and do not spend any time finding
improvements to the solution. In natural systems, of course, existing solutions are constantly
tested and improved over the course of time and the concept can be applied here as well.
We may be able to achieve this by applying a "hillclimbing" algorithm to the
successful solution that has been returned by the GA search mechanism (Figure 6.1). This
algorithm would attempt to minimize the cost value of the solution while ensuring that the
solution still works. For each iteration the algorithm would generate a slightly modified
version of the original solution, perhaps through the mutation of an existing operation or by
adding or removing an operation at a random location in the program. This slightly modified
version is then tested using the original fitness function used in the GA search mechanism.
Should it fail, the original solution will be used for mutation in the subsequent iteration.
Should it pass, the solution with the smaller cost value
will be selected for the subsequent
iteration. The algorithm terminates after a given threshold number of iterations have been
completed. This threshold value may perhaps be set as twice the size of the original solution
as this would likely allow most potential combinations to be tested.
Although the system was able to solve almost all basic arithmetic operations, it was
unable to solve two important ones: division and modulus. This may be due to a lack of
counting ability that is a limitation of the programming language. Division, as an operation,
involves repeatedly subtracting the divisor from the dividend and counting the number of
times that this action was performed. Since the language lacks any knowledge of constants, it
is unable to count, and thus unable to divide.
A possible solution might be to create a basic instruction "ZERO" that injects the
constant value zero as the next input value for consumption. In keeping with the minimalist
spirit of the language, all other constants would need to be derived as a combination of the
ZERO and INC instructions. For example, for injecting a constant value of one, the
subprogram
{ { ZERO } INC }
would need to be used. For larger constants, a combination of
smaller constants could be used. For example, to derive an operation that injects the constant
value sixty-four (64) into the input stream, the subprogram might invoke the multiplication
subprogram on the constant values four and sixteen.
Clearly, the addition of constants increases the field of potential subprograms
dramatically and if all constants were programmed in as individual instructions (e.g. the ONE
instruction, TWO instruction, etc.) the search space for the GA would start out far larger than
any of the programs that it was able to solve for this project. However, since only one of the
constants is hardcoded, the system may derive only the ones it needs to use for a particular
task thus keeping the search space small.
The programming language in its current form is unable to support recursion. This is
due to the subprograms being added to the Instruction Pool and assigned operation codes,
which can then be used by other subprograms, only after they have successfully completed a
given task. This has not necessarily stopped the system from performing tasks that lend
themselves nicely to recursive routines, but a recursion language feature may increase the
system's performance. For example, the Addition (4.4.3) or Multiplication (4.6.1) tasks are
typical cases where recursion can be applied easily since the definitions are themselves
recursive. In these cases, the system found solutions using the LOOP instruction to
repeatedly call the same routine multiple times. But if the language supported recursion, the
solutions for these tasks may become more efficient both to discover and to execute.
This could be implemented with a new basic instruction "RECURSE" that pauses the
execution of the current program and calls itself again. The I/O semantics would be the same
as having called any other subprogram. The addition of this instruction may allow for smaller
solutions, which in effect increases the likelihood that they'll be discovered, at the relatively
small cost of increasing the search space from n
to (n + 1)
